metadata.titleEn: Global high-resolution simulated near sea surface temperature precipitation SST dataset (1990-2020)
metadata.description: The global high-resolution simulated near sea surface temperature precipitation SST data set from 1990 to 2020 is from the latest cmip6 project. Cmip6 is the sixth climate model comparison program organized by the world climate research project (WCRP). Original data source: https://www.wcrp-climate.org/wgcm-cmip/wgcm-cmip6 。 The data set includes the global near ocean surface temperature (TMP), precipitation (PR) and sea surface temperature (TOS). The air temperature and precipitation data include the rectangular combination of shared social economic path (SSP) and representative concentration path (RCP) of four different experimental scenarios of scenario MIP in cmip6. (1) Ssp126: upgrade rcp2.6 scenario based on ssp1 (low forcing scenario) (radiation forcing will reach 2.6w/m2 in 2100). (2) Ssp245: upgrade rcp4.5 scenario based on SSP2 (moderate forcing scenario) (radiation forcing will reach 4.5 w / m2 in 2100). (3) Ssp370: a new rcp7.0 emission path based on ssp3 (medium forcing scenario) (radiation forcing will reach 7.0 w / m2 in 2100). (4) Ssp585: upgrade rcp8.5 scenario based on ssp5 (high forcing scenario) (ssp585 is the only SSP scenario that can make radiation forcing reach 8.5 w / m2 in 2100). SST data provides ssp126 scenario data.
metadata.instructions:
1. Data size: 45 g
2. Data format: netcdf4
3. Folder structure
(1) Precipitation pr
./pr 
./ssp126
./ pr_ Amon_ BCC-CSM2-MR_ ssp126_ r1i1p1f1_ 0.5deg_ gn_ 199001-202012.nc
(2) Temperature TMP
./tmp
./ssp126
./ tmp_ Amon_ BCC-CSM2-MR_ ssp126_ r1i1p1f1_ 0.5deg_ gn_ 199001-202012.nc
(3) SST TOS
/tos
./tos_ Omon_ BCC-CSM2-MR_ r1i1p1f1_ gn_ 199001-202012.nc
Naming rules:
<variable_ name>/
<temporal resolution>/
<model_ name>/
<ssp>/
<member_ id>/
<spatial resolution>/
<grid_ label>/
<time_ range>/
<variable_ Name > / refers to the name of the variable, PR refers to precipitation, TMP refers to temperature, and TOS refers to SST.
<temporary resolution>/ refers to the time resolution, and amon and OMON both represent the monthly scale.
<model_ Name > / indicates which mode it belongs to, bcc-csm2-mr.
<ssp>/ represents the greenhouse gas emission scenario.
<member_ ID > / are some control indicators of the operation mode. member_ Id = r<k>i<l>p<m>f<n>, where k=realization_ index； l=initialization_ index； m=physics_ index； n=forcing_ index
<spatial_ Resolution > / indicates spatial resolution.
<grid_ Label> indicates the type of grid for the output data.
<time_ Range> indicates the data time range.

literatureList.titleEn: Overview of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) experimental design and organization
literatureList.referenceEn: Eyring, V., Bony, S., Meehl, G.A., Senior, C.A., Stevens, B., Stouffer, R.J., & Taylor, K.E. (2016). Overview of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) experimental design and organization, Geosci. Model Dev., 9, 1937-1958, doi:10.5194/gmd-9-1937-2016.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collected in global high-resolution simulations for near-surface air temperature, precipitation, and sea surface temperature from 1990-2020?
Feature Specification.Answer: global near-surface air temperature, precipitation, sea surface temperature, SSP126, SSP245, SSP370, SSP585

Quantification.Question: How many different shared socioeconomic pathways (SSPs) and representative concentration pathways (RCPs) combinations are included in a global high-resolution simulated dataset of near-ocean surface air temperature, precipitation, and sea surface temperature from 1990 to 2020?

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'shared socioeconomic pathway' (SSP) in the context of climate modeling datasets?
Definition.Answer: In the context of climate modeling datasets, 'shared socioeconomic pathway' (SSP) refers to a scenario framework that describes different pathways of societal development and their implications on climate change. SSPs are used to model potential futures based on varying levels of socioeconomic challenges for mitigation and adaptation, combined with representative concentration pathways (RCPs) to assess climate impacts. For example, SSP126 represents a low-forcing scenario that builds on SSP1 with RCP2.6, indicating a scenario where radiative forcing reaches 2.6 W/m2 by 2100.

Comparison.Question: How do the experimental scenarios SSP126 and SSP585 compare in terms of their approach to modeling future climate conditions using shared socioeconomic pathways and representative concentration pathways?
Comparison.Answer: The SSP126 scenario is based on SSP1, which represents a low forcing scenario, and is an upgrade of the RCP2.6 scenario, with a radiative forcing reaching 2.6 W/m2 by 2100. In contrast, the SSP585 scenario is based on SSP5, representing a high forcing scenario, and is an upgrade of the RCP8.5 scenario, with the radiative forcing reaching 8.5 W/m2 by 2100. These scenarios provide different pathways for socioeconomic development and emissions, impacting the modeling of future climate conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on data accuracy and model predictions when applying different shared socioeconomic pathways (SSP) and representative concentration pathways (RCP) combinations to simulate global near-surface air temperature and precipitation data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Different SSP and RCP combinations can result in varied data accuracy and model predictions due to differing assumptions about socioeconomic factors and radiative forcing levels. For instance, SSP126 represents a low forcing scenario, while SSP585 represents a high forcing scenario, affecting the projected near-surface air temperature, precipitation, and sea temperature data. These scenarios provide insights into potential climate outcomes, helping to assess the impacts of different climate policies and socioeconomic developments on future climate conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind collecting global high-resolution simulation data of near-surface oceanic air temperature, precipitation, and sea surface temperature from 1990 to 2020?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives behind collecting global high-resolution simulation data of near-surface oceanic air temperature, precipitation, and sea surface temperature from 1990 to 2020 are to facilitate comprehensive climate modeling and comparison through the CMIP6 initiative. This effort aims to understand the impacts of various shared socioeconomic pathways (SSPs) and representative concentration pathways (RCPs) on climate projections, providing insights into potential future climate scenarios and aiding in climate change mitigation and adaptation strategies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are utilized to integrate different experimental scenarios like SSP126, SSP245, SSP370, and SSP585 in the global high-resolution simulation of near-surface ocean air temperature, precipitation, and sea surface temperature data collection?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection utilizes a matrix combination of shared socioeconomic pathways (SSP) and representative concentration pathways (RCP) specific to each experimental scenario. These scenarios are based on updates to existing RCP scenarios under different SSPs, with each scenario representing different levels of radiative forcing by the year 2100: SSP126 with 2.6 W/m2, SSP245 with 4.5 W/m2, SSP370 with 7.0 W/m2, and SSP585 with 8.5 W/m2. These combinations are part of the ScenarioMIP under CMIP6, which are integrated to simulate the variables of interest.
